natural problem: Simplify: $x(3x^2-2)-5(x^2-2x+7)$. Express your answer in the form $Ax^3+Bx^2+Cx+D.$
natural solution: Using the distributive property and combining like terms: \begin{align} x(3x^2-2)-5(x^2-2x+7) &= 3x^3-2x-5x^2+10x-35\\ & = \boxed{3x^3-5x^2+8x-35}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (3 * x powr 2 - 2)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 5 * (x powr 2 - 2 * x + 7)"
shows  "P x - Q x = 3 * x powr 3 - 5 * x powr 2 + 8 * x - 35"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Simplify: $x(3x^2-2)-5(x^2-2x+7)$. Express your answer in the form $Ax^3+Bx^2+Cx+D.$ The final Answer is 3x^3-5x^2+8x-35
 ### Proof
 Using the distributive property and combining like terms: \begin{align} x(3x^2-2)-5(x^2-2x+7) &= 3x^3-2x-5x^2+10x-35\\ & = \boxed{3x^3-5x^2+8x-35}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x * (3 * x powr 2 - 2)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 5 * (x powr 2 - 2 * x + 7)"
shows  "P x - Q x = 3 * x powr 3 - 5 * x powr 2 + 8 * x - 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = x * (3x^2 - 2)$ and $Q(x) = 5 * (x^2 - 2x + 7)$, find the difference between $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$. The final answer is $3x^3 - 5x^2 + 8x - 35$.
